Award.AwardTitle: Evolution of silencing proteins in yeast

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit The advent of new DNA sequencing technologies and a wealth of sequenced genomes have intensified the need to develop innovative approaches for extracting functional insights from these data. Although homology is a useful principle, homologous proteins sometimes have different functions across species, and these differences can reconfigure regulatory pathways governing how organisms respond to environmental changes. Consequently, extrapolating function from model species can be misleading. To understand how proteins acquire new functions and the biological consequences of these changes, this project focuses on a group of proteins named Sir2 deacetylases, which are found in all kingdoms of life. These enzymes are proposed to coordinate life-cycle transitions with nutrient availability. Importantly, Sir2 deacetylases display varied modes of action and may enable species-specific responses to nutritional conditions. This project employs a combination of genome-scale and classical functional studies to investigate the evolutionary history of Sir2 in genetically tractable yeast species. The first part of the project examines how Sir2 orthologs have evolved new functions by acquiring interactions with a variety of protein complexes that repress gene expression, and the second part explores the consequences of such changes as they relate to the physiology of cells. To elucidate the steps by which Sir2 acquired its function in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the functions of Sir2 orthologs will be compared in species at appropriate evolutionary distances from S. cerevisiae, namely in Candida lusitaniae, a representative species of the Candida clade, and in the yeast Kluyveromyces lactis. As these species have different responses to nutrient levels in terms of specific aspects of their physiology, this project has the potential to elucidate the roles of Sir2 in such responses.
Broader Impact This project will provide training opportunities for two graduate students, several Duke undergraduate students conducting independent studies, and summer students participating in two programs designed to encourage disadvantaged students to pursue careers in science. The Duke Summer Research Opportunity Program (SROP) targets undergraduates, and the North Carolina Section Project SEED program supports high school students. In addition, this project will promote the recruitment and retention of female scientists by supporting the careers of a graduate student and the principal investigator, who are both women. Finally, the development of additional yeast species, such as K. lactis and C. lusitaniae, as model organisms will greatly facilitate future studies in molecular evolution by enabling researchers to test their hypotheses using multiple experimentally tractable yeast species that are separated by hundreds of millions of years of evolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:     The major questions this project addressed are (i) how protein functions change over evolutionary time and (ii) how such changes enable species to develop new traits. As a case study, we focused on Sirtuin proteins. This family of proteins is regulatory, meaning that sirtuins switch cellular processes on and off by removing a chemical mark (acetyl group) from other proteins. The sirtuins we studied (Sir2/Hst1) turn genes off by removing this chemical mark from proteins that package DNA. Importantly, sirtuins only remove this chemical mark in the presence of a metabolite (NAD+) that is derived from vitamin B3 and modified (reduced) as energy is extracted from sugar. The requirement for this metabolite suggests that sirtuins respond to the metabolic state of the cell. Consequently, genes regulated by sirtuins may be switched on in coordination with metabolism and nutrient availability. Thus, over evolutionary time, if sirtuins change such that they regulate different genes, these changes can allow species to acquire new, adaptive responses to low nutrients. To test this model, the overall goal of the project was to trace changes in the Sir2/Hst1 group of sirtuins by (i) elucidating the biological functions of these proteins in two strategic yeast species, Clavispora lusitaniae and Kluyveromyces lactis, and (ii) comparing the functions in these species with known functions in previously studied yeast species.

Outcomes (Intellectual Merit):     Our research revealed that the biological functions of Sir2 proteins are surprisingly plastic. This plasticity arises through two mechanisms. First, the SIR2 gene has undergone several duplications and losses. Duplications produce extra genetic material that can acquire new functions, and gene losses eliminate particular Sir2 functions from a lineage. The second mechanism that promotes plasticity is the capacity of Sir2 to interact with various adaptor proteins that bring it to different genes. Thus, although the ability of Sir2 to remove acetyl groups has not changed, its target genes have changed and hence the biological output of its regulatory action has changed.  This discovery led us to the model that Sir2/Hst1 proteins serve as rewiring points, which allow species to evolve distinct adaptations to low nutrient conditions by bringing new cellular processes under the control of Sir2. This model can be generalized. Transcription factors and other regulatory enzymes may also achieve biological plasticity through similar mechanisms.

Outcomes (Broader Impacts):       This project supported training of the next generation of scientists (one postdoctoral fellow, two graduate students, one research associate, ten undergraduates, and one high school student).  Moreover, the project contributed to a diverse scientific workforce, as it supported seven women (one postdoctoral fellow, two graduate students, one research associate, and three undergrads) and three underrepresented minority undergraduates. Trainees attended weekly lab meetings and journal clubs and had regularly scheduled meetings with the principal investigator to discuss research progress.
